summary: This is a defense filing by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys (Haddon, Morgan and Foreman) addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan. It responds to government letters regarding a Rule 17(c) subpoena for evidence held by the law firm Boies, Schiller & Flexner (BSF). The filing argues the government is improperly handling evidence, including a journal from 'Accuser-2,' a pair of boots, and photographs, and accuses the prosecution of selective disclosure and failing to properly investigate exculpatory material.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). Her defense team is filing this response to argue for access to evidence they claim is being improperly withheld or mishandled by the government.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her, requesting rulings on subpoenaed evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman who signed the filing. He is part of Maxwell's defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and co-conspirator. The journal of 'Accuser-2' describes interactions with him, and the case involves allegations related to his activities.

persons.name: Accuser-2
persons.context: An alleged victim represented by BSF. She kept a journal in 1996 describing interactions with Jeffrey Epstein. The defense seeks her full journal, not just selectively produced pages.

persons.name: Michael Baker
persons.context: Host of The Daily Podcast for The New York Times, referenced in a transcript where Accuser-2 discussed using her journal to refresh her memory.

connections.description: The indictment references Maxwell's interactions with Accuser-2 at Epstein's residence, implicating their association in the alleged crimes.
Accuser-2's journal describes her interactions with Epstein, and she is an alleged victim in the case.
Accuser-2 sued Maxwell and is a witness against her. Maxwell's defense is seeking evidence (the journal) from Accuser-2.
Pagliuca is an attorney from the firm representing Maxwell, as evidenced by his signature on the filing.
Accuser-2 has been represented by the law firm BSF since approximately 2016. The firm is in possession of her journal and other evidence.

events.title: Maxwell's Subpoena Application
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell asked the court to issue a Rule 17(c) subpoena for evidence controlled by the law firm Boies, Schiller & Flexner (BSF).

events.title: Accuser-2's Journal Entries
events.description: The period when 'Accuser-2' kept a journal documenting her interactions with Jeffrey Epstein. The defense argues the full journal is needed for context.

events.title: Defense Review of Physical Evidence
events.description: Maxwell and her lawyers traveled to New York to review physical evidence in the government's possession, including original photographs.

events.title: NY Times Daily Podcast Episode
events.description: Accuser-2 discussed her journal and interactions with Epstein on The Daily podcast, stating she used the journal to refresh her memory.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007 (United States District Court, Southern District of New York)
Denver, Colorado 80203 (Location of law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman)
New Mexico (Mentioned as location of Epstein's residence where Maxwell allegedly interacted with Accuser-2)
New York (Mentioned as location where Accuser-2's journal documents encounters with Epstein)
keyFacts: The defense accuses the government of 'selective disclosure' regarding a journal from 'Accuser-2,' having only 7 photocopied pages (5 substantive) out of the full journal, which the government admits it has never read or possessed.
The defense argues the full journal is exculpatory because the absence of any mention of Ghislaine Maxwell in entries contemporaneous with alleged events could undermine the prosecution's case.

The defense raises concerns about evidence authenticity, noting discrepancies between photocopies of the same journal entry produced in civil vs. criminal discovery, suggesting potential manipulation.

The government is attempting to 'moot' a defense subpoena request for a pair of boots by having the FBI secure them, which the defense argues interferes with Maxwell's ability to investigate her case.

The filing cites legal doctrines like the 'fairness doctrine' and Federal Rules of Evidence 106 and 612 to argue for the production of the complete journal, especially since the witness used it to refresh her memory.
